title: Will S&P, Moody's, or Fitch change Chile's long-term foreign currency rating before 29 June 2018?
preds: Nothing in the news and we're a couple of days away.

Helpful to keep in mind Bloomberg reported that the World Bank was accused of bias after cooking the books to issue an overly optimistic forecast on the eve of Pinera's election. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-13/chile-demands-answers-in-world-bank-business-ranking-controversy
Copper has rallied ~15% since last July , when it's rating was originally cut.
Unless I’m missing something the deadline is in just six weeks, except for Moody’s everyone is stable, and nothing big is happening to the economy in the time frame.

1) For there to be a change, there has to be a review.  My guess is that each agency reviews countries on a regular schedule.  The schedule may be tied to specific economic releases for the country region and world ( commodities market in particular ). Looking at seasonal times the report has been done in the past here:  https://tradingeconomics.com/chile/rating , I see 2/37 reviews done between May 19 and June 29th.   
Adding a bit for uncertainty, starting with a 7% chance a review even happens. 2) If there is a review, paying attention to just S&P changes, there were 11 reviews and 6 changes since 1992.  
Cut the 7% down to 3.5% for a review and change. 3) Would there be a reason for a change if there was a review?
I'll use GDP growth as indicator because S&P analysts seem to frequently quote it in their explanations. When Chile was first upgraded to AA- by S&P in 2012, it expected GDP growth of 5.5% after having experienced 6% in 2010 and 2011:
https://www.reuters.com/article/chile-ratings-sandp/update-2-sp-raises-chiles-credit-rating-to-aa-minus-idUSL1E8NQ6KM20121226. When Chile was downgraded to A+ in 2017, S&P analysts quoted GDP growth of 2% predicted for 2018.
https://www.ft.com/content/0c5abd69-b085-3dfd-a1da-a4bd9818de7f Now Chile is experiencing growth of 4.2%. http://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/banking/chile-watch-q1-gdp-growth-tax-rules-for-digital-assets/. Rounding down from 3.5% to 2% because even if review happens, I see the most likely outcome as no-change.
If they do revise it, the rating will go up (http://santiagotimes.cl/tag/economy/) due to low inflation, strong growth, and a basket case next door in Argentina.
